name: Fagradalsfjall - The Tourist Volcano of Reykjanes Peninsula
description: Fagradalsfjall volcanic system on Reykjanes Peninsula became Iceland's most accessible and visitor-friendly volcanic eruption when fissure vent opened March 19, 2021, ending 815-year volcanic dormancy on peninsula and initiating series of three spectacular eruptions (2021, 2022, 2023) that attracted hundreds of thousands of tourists, photographers, scientists, and adventurers who could safely observe active lava fountaining, flowing rivers of molten rock, and volcanic processes from established viewing areas mere hundreds of meters from eruption sites—accessibility unprecedented in modern volcanology where most eruptions occur in remote, dangerous, or restricted locations. The 2021 eruption beginning March 19 in Geldingadalir valley south of Fagradalsfjall mountain continued six months until September 18, producing spectacular lava fountains reaching heights of 100+ meters, creating lava flows that gradually filled valley floor while remaining safely distant from infrastructure allowing authorities to establish hiking trails, viewing platforms, and emergency protocols enabling public access throughout eruption duration in remarkable volcanic tourism experiment. The effusive character producing fluid basaltic lava flows rather than explosive pyroclastic eruptions meant visitors could approach within safe distances without facing ash clouds, pyroclastic surges, or volcanic bombs that characterize more dangerous explosive volcanism, though regulations required maintaining minimum distances and evacuating when conditions deteriorated or new vents opened unexpectedly.
